results.title: Weather: understanding precipitation
results.brief_description: Use of cloud photography and animation to explain relative humidity, dew point, types of clouds, and why various kinds of preciipitaiton occur. Explains precipitation in terms of water and temperature. Classifies clouds according to how they are formed and according to their altitudes.
results.description: Use of cloud photography and animation to explain relative humidity, dew point, types of clouds, and why various kinds of preciipitaiton occur. results.title: Weather: sunshine
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Janet Lane
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
An educational series aimed at 6-8 year olds which covers a variety of subject areas such as weather, transport, space, people and celebrations. This short video describes how the sun creates shadows on the ground and reflections on the water; how as the world rotates, the sun sets on one side of the world and rises on the other; and how people and animals use the sun differently. Suitable for children aged 3-7.

results.title: Weather: rain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This video is mostly a visual exploration of rain as it falls on a rain forest. There is a child with yellow rain coat and rain hat walking through the rain and speaking of the rain and how things can be appreciated differently as it falls. The water rushes and runs gathering in streams. The child visits the zoo to watch the animals in the rain who don’t seem as fussed about the rain as humans do, drinking from the sky. The child ends up in the playground enjoying the rain here also.

results.title: Weather: hot
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Caroline Jones
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
An educational series aimed at 6-8 year olds which covers a variety of subject areas such as weather, transport, space, people and celebrations. When it is hot outside, people wear shorts and t-shirts, drink lots of water, and modify their usual activities to help keep cool. The question is why do we do this? Suitable for children aged 3-7, this video describes how changes in weather affect people, plants and animals differently and the different methods each use to adapt and cope with the heat; what a thermometer is and what it does; how to observe and monitor changes in the weather; and why it is important to dress appropriately when it is hot outside. Also briefly discusses the sun as an energy source.

Suitable for children aged 3-7, this video describes how changes in weather affect people, plants and animals differently and the different methods each use to adapt and cope with the heat; what a thermometer is and what it does; how to observe and monitor changes in the weather; and why it is important to dress appropriately when it is hot outside. Also briefly discusses the sun as an energy source.

results.title: Weather: dry
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Caroline Jones
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video explains the dry weather and its characteristics. It explains humidity and the effects dry weather has on farms and nature. The video talks of drought and how animals can adapt to periods of dry weather and also the effects of water wastage and conservation. Koalas and camels feature.

results.title: Weather: cold
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video for children covers the topic of cold weather. There are scenes of frosty mornings and the reasons why nights can be so cold, especially when they are cloudless. There are ways and reasons to stay warm and how animals like sheep and horses keep warm during the cold months. The video explains how penguins and whales stay warm, mentioning migration and hibernation as ways animals survive the cold weather. Cold weather and seasons are also important to explain why you can’t buy vegetables all year round.

results.title: Weather satellites
results.brief_description: Explains the importance of weather satellites in recording and relaying pictures of wind and cloud patterns to strategically located receiving stations, thereby enabling meteorologists to spot the early formation of dangerous conditions such as typhoons, hurricanes and tornadoes.
results.description: Explains the importance of weather satellites in recording and relaying pictures of wind and cloud patterns to strategically located receiving stations, thereby enabling meteorologists to spot the early formation of dangerous conditions such as typhoons, hurricanes and tornadoes.

results.title: Weather forecast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World Is Ours”.
International cooperation in weather forecasting. Radio communications system controlled by the World Meteorological Organisation of the United Nations. Numerous examples of how weather forecasting can reduce or eliminate the danger and damage of hurricanes, gales and high tides. Weather studies in the reclamation of desert areas.

results.title: Weather does its thing
results.creator_credit: United Nations, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Selig Alkon
results.brief_description: The film looks at the human relationship to climate and shows how in the past we have changed our weather for the worse. The World Weather Watch is followed and the interchange of facts taking place between the World Weather Watch Centres at Washington, Moscow and Melbourne is seen. The significance of WWW is explained by David A. Davies, Secretary-General of the World Meteorological Organisation.

results.title: Weather diary #5
results.brief_description: The latest chapter’ of the remarkable Weather Diary series finds Kuchar observing his personal, social and natural environment with wry humor and introspection. Writes Kuchar:Set in central Oklahoma during May, I spend 3 weeks in a motel and get talked at by a small weather-radio that seems to rule my life. I, myself, get to talk at the lady who runs the motel and who runs a cosmetic empire downtown. The viewer gets to see her equipment and her corner of the world as storms lurk somewhere off-camera, waiting to enter stage left and bring down the house. This is one of the more social installments of the weather diary series’.
